Posts.Content: If you're only having stress incontinence (even a lot) and don't leak at night, you're light years ahead of many guys at your stage. Like mtsarpilot said, ditch the caffeine and citrus drinks. Caffeine and citrus drinks cause the bladder to spasm, hence the leaks. Stick with water. I do pretty good most of the week, but on Saturdays (like today) I like to pressure test the bladder with about 8 beers, and I leak like a sieve. But on Sunday it's back to normal (just some stress incontinence). Only 5 days after catheter removal, you're doing great and it should improve as every week goes by. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RickRed52 I for one was not informed. I think what disturbed me the most was that no one ever mentioned the possibility of climacturia. (urination-before, during or after climax) Of all the things I was not told about, this one ticks me off the most. One thing everybody should be aware of is that no matter what kind of patient you are, YOU are responsible for your care. Not the doctor, nurse, or anybody else. YOU. Honestly, I don't know how anyone considering surgery and having done any research at all could not have been aware of the possibility of climacturia prior to surgery. The cancer boards are filled with threads about it. Walsh's book talks about it. The American Cancer Society has at minimum four different references to it on their web site.

Posts.Title: Erections Post Surgery

Posts.Content: Well, I hate to brag and usually don't. I don't even post "Hey, I'm still a zero" posts. I just don't want to make anyone else feel bad. But I'm 57 years old, two years post-RALP, and I'm getting the wood on like I was when I was seventeen. Granted it takes a Viagra do to it, but my non-Viagra erections are every bit as good as my erections just prior to surgery. Maybe even better. Since my prostate is gone, it seems that the blood flows even better. Erections seem just a little bit bigger, and and certainly more, umm, sensitive. Try taking the meds on an empty stomach, makes a world of difference for me. Dan

Posts.Title: Incontenence

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RickRed52 In one of my surveys of the 153 men who responded 37% said knowing what they know today about life without a prostate they would not have chosen surgery. What would be a very revealing follow-up question for these men is who and how experienced their surgeon was. How may of them did any research at all prior to undergoing surgery? Also, of that 37%, what percentage of those do you suppose would have also regretted a different treatment option down the road? Lots of guys have gotten plenty screwed up by radiation. Others have not had their cancer cured. The guys who had surgery don't know what life would have been like had they had another form of treatment. I wonder if there is a similar survey somewhere of guys who had radiation, HT, etc. Maybe 37% of them wished they had opted for surgery. I also noticed that only 11% of the survey guys were solidly in the "regret my decision/ruined my life" camp. I'm not criticizing your position or survey, mind you. Just thinking out loud.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by KW2014 Thanks for the reply, I am marginally leaning towards surgery for the reasons you highlighted. However, the increased risk of side effects are a concern to me. I appreciate whatever input everyone can give with personal experiences to help me make this decision. You will also find that the chances of making a good recovery from those side effects is better the younger you are, and that the experience of the surgeon has a lot to do with both the success of the surgery and the minimization of side effects. Sorry to have you join us. Good luck on your decision/treatment.

Posts.Title: Brachytherapy versus Robotic (daVinci)

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by KW2014 Due to insurance I would be using a local surgeon, he has done hundreds of open surgery procedures but only about 25 da Vinci operatons. I am a bit concerned about the experience factor, but he is about my age and did come to the local clinic from Sloan-Kettering so he has solid experience and training. Personally, I wouldn't let a guy that's only done 25 robotics anywhere near my prostate. If he's done several hundred open procedures, you might want to consider going that way if you are absolutely tied to this guy because of your insurance. Having a lot of experience doing opens doesn't translate into being a good robotic surgeon. It's a whole different ball game and the learning experience of the robot is quite steep, on the order of several hundred procedures. The first thing I would do is find out what his outcomes are. He should have that information. If they aren't good, I'd be doing battle with my insurance company to get me to a guy who's outcomes are good. No do-overs here. Good luck to you.

Posts.Content: I am inferring from this article that the new test will be more accurate than reading biopsy samples with a microscope in the traditional fashion, but will still be dependent on whether or not the urologist hits the worst part of the tumor with the biopsy needle. And if that's the case, we are still left with the same problem of not knowing for sure what grade the cancer really is. Just more sure of the grade the needle found.

Try taking the meds on an empty stomach, makes a world of difference for me. Dan

(urination-before, during or after climax) Of all the things I was not told about, this one ticks me off the most. One thing everybody should be aware of is that no matter what kind of patient you are, YOU are responsible for your care. Not the doctor, nurse, or anybody else. YOU. Honestly, I don't know how anyone considering surgery and having done any research at all could not have been aware of the possibility of climacturia prior to surgery. The cancer boards are filled with threads about it. Walsh's book talks about it. The American Cancer Society has at minimum four different references to it on their web site.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RickRed52 In one of my surveys of the 153 men who responded 37% said knowing what they know today about life without a prostate they would not have chosen surgery. What would be a very revealing follow-up question for these men is who and how experienced their surgeon was. How may of them did any research at all prior to undergoing surgery? Also, of that 37%, what percentage of those do you suppose would have also regretted a different treatment option down the road? Lots of guys have gotten plenty screwed up by radiation. Others have not had their cancer cured. The guys who had surgery don't know what life would have been like had they had another form of treatment. I wonder if there is a similar survey somewhere of guys who had radiation, HT, etc. Maybe 37% of them wished they had opted for surgery. I also noticed that only 11% of the survey guys were solidly in the "regret my decision/ruined my life" camp. I'm not criticizing your position or survey, mind you. Just thinking out loud.

Posts.Title: Erections Post Surgery

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by KW2014 Due to insurance I would be using a local surgeon, he has done hundreds of open surgery procedures but only about 25 da Vinci operatons. I am a bit concerned about the experience factor, but he is about my age and did come to the local clinic from Sloan-Kettering so he has solid experience and training. Personally, I wouldn't let a guy that's only done 25 robotics anywhere near my prostate. If he's done several hundred open procedures, you might want to consider going that way if you are absolutely tied to this guy because of your insurance. Having a lot of experience doing opens doesn't translate into being a good robotic surgeon. It's a whole different ball game and the learning experience of the robot is quite steep, on the order of several hundred procedures. The first thing I would do is find out what his outcomes are. He should have that information. If they aren't good, I'd be doing battle with my insurance company to get me to a guy who's outcomes are good. No do-overs here. Good luck to you.

Posts.Content: I am inferring from this article that the new test will be more accurate than reading biopsy samples with a microscope in the traditional fashion, but will still be dependent on whether or not the urologist hits the worst part of the tumor with the biopsy needle. And if that's the case, we are still left with the same problem of not knowing for sure what grade the cancer really is. Just more sure of the grade the needle found.

Posts.Title: What lies ahead

Posts.Content: A 70 percenter ought to have you smiling at this stage of the game. Should be plenty adequate. Have you been doing kegels to help with urinary control? You need to make doing a kegel when you cough, laugh, bend over, sit up, etc almost second nature. That will help with a lot of the dribbling. Everybody's recovery is different, so if you get 20 responses to this, there will be 20 different recovery stories. I never had much more than an occasional dribble (except very early after surgery when I drank a lot of beer) and consider myself to be 100% continent now. And a 70 percenter makes ME smile. Well, not just me. Good luck on your recovery. Dan

Posts.Title: Surgery Tomorrow

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by doinalright Thanks Dan, Does the urinating and the erections gradually get better or is it like wake up one day and "hello there"? The answer is: Depends. (See, I made a funny) I never had to change pads, other guys have to change pads for months or years. Some guys get gradually better erections, but I just read a post the other day on one of the boards from a guy who went a couple of years and then all of a sudden had nice erections again. Mine seem to be getting gradually (very gradually) better, but they are adequate. And based on what I've been through and the experiences of many other PC guys, I think I'm doing really well. Do you drink coffee or citrus juice? If so, I would recommend stopping for a while and see if that helps. Both cause bladder spasms and make it difficult to control the dribbles.

Posts.Title: Milestones of recovery

Posts.Content: Your doctor "feels" it's prostatitis? Are you willing to bet your life on that? Your PSA is outside what would be considered the normal range for someone your age. Something's causing it. You need to find out what. The other guys are quite correct, the chances of it being prostate cancer are pretty remote. But not outside the realm of possiblity. Plenty of guys on these boards who were diagnosed in their thirties. I'm not trying to scare you, but you need a little better answer than your guy "feels" it's prosatitis. Hopefully, it is. But you need to find out. And not in four years. More like four months. If that. The advice to see a urologist is spot on. By the way, is there a family history you're aware of? You might want to ask around. After I was diagnosed, I found out that many of my uncles and one of my grandfathers had it. Best of luck to you Dan

Posts.Title: Robotic surgery vs hands

Posts.Content: I am not a doctor. This is not medical advice. I may be full of $*&@. Pee is sterile. Who cares if there's a little leak? Ask him what the consequences of removing the catheter while there's a little leak are. Mine was in for 6 days. No cystogram. Just a nurse yanking it out and measuring my output. I'll bet tens of thousands of guys have their catheters removed while there's still a little leak. Your mileage may vary.

Posts.Title: Having problems, now 11 weeks after Davinci....any suggestions welcome

Posts.Content: You probably won't feel much like working for about two weeks. I was back to lengthy walks after a couple of weeks, and hit the elliptical at around three. That was a tad too soon. I took another week off from the gym and then hit it again at about four weeks, which was fine for elliptical training. At the same time I cheated a little and did a few bicep curls on the machine and some abdominal work, but both with very little resistance. I was 55 and in pretty good shape prior to surgery. I let my body tell me what it was ready for. I was scuba diving at a little over three weeks but had my buds haul my stuff into the water for me so I didn't have to carry any weight at all. But I also tend to be a risk taker, so don't take this as sound medical advice. Or even crappy medical advice.

Posts.Title: Robotic surgery vs hands

Posts.Content: Welcome. Glad to see you that you did your research and found a surgeon with a bit of experience. Your story is exactly why I didn't mess around getting into surgery; I didn't want to take the chance that the biopsy was wrong. You mention incontinence but talk about having to go to the bathroom frequently, are you actually leaking or just have to go frequently? Sometimes it takes several months for the bladder to return to its normal shape and capacity after a prostatectomy if you had an enlarged prostate. If you're having a leakage problem, cut off all the caffeine and citrus drinks for a while and see if that helps. Both cause bladder spasms. I leaked a little for a couple of months after surgery and still have an occasional drip if I'm not careful. Do a kegel when you stand up, bend over, cough, etc if that's when you're having problems. Good luck Dan

Posts.Title: My story and a question

Posts.Content: I am not a doctor. This is not medical advice. I may be full of $*&@. Pee is sterile. Who cares if there's a little leak? Ask him what the consequences of removing the catheter while there's a little leak are. Mine was in for 6 days. No cystogram. Just a nurse yanking it out and measuring my output. I'll bet tens of thousands of guys have their catheters removed while there's still a little leak. Your mileage may vary.

Posts.Title: post radiation PSA results at 18 months after treatment completed

Posts.Content: Travel? Yeah, I traveled - About 6500 miles one way from Guam to Los Angeles and then back again. I arrived a couple of days early for my pre-op appointment and to get situated. I had my procedure done at City of Hope, they had hospice cottages and we rented one for about 10 days. We stayed there until the catheter was out (7 days) and then drove up to the SF area to catch a flight to Hawaii. The drive was long but not unbearable. If your guy's in decent shape he should be able to handle a 4-5 hour drive after a week (maybe sooner, but a week is my experience). I wouldn't, however, head out on a 6500 mile flight after a week knowing what I do now. I made it, but it was extremely unpleasant. I wouldn't consider a DaVinci with anyone less than 1000 procedures under their belt. It's a one-shot deal, if the surgeon screws it up there's no second chances. Review their outcomes and even interview them if you need to. I interviewed a couple over the phone from Guam and ruled them out. If they won't divulge their outcomes (successful cancer removal/negative margins, continence, and sexual potency) then run away. You'll hear a lot of advice that getting the cancer out is the number one outcome and that everything else is secondary. I wouldn't disagree with that. But with the DaVinci and a surgeon who really knows his way around it, there's no reason not to try to shoot for the trifecta. And that generally won't be a guy with 300-400 procedures. Could be, but I'd go with the odds..... Good luck. Dan

Posts.Title: Post Surgery; blood in urine.

Posts.Content: My lifting restriction was for six weeks. After that my doc told me I was limited to what my body could handle. I power walk in addition to elliptical training. Three-four weeks after surgery I was back up to three plus miles a day (albeit a little slower than normal). But it wasn't long after that I was back to my usual speed. I jumped on the elliptical at about three weeks but that was a little too much, so I laid off that for another week then eased back in. I wouldn't mess with bands or anything like that, because if you're standing up it's going to strain your abdomen. Now, I found that I could do some bicep curls if I was on a machine that totally isolated the biceps. But I kept the weight down a bit. Started that about four weeks post surgery. I also did a few ab crunchs at a little over four weeks, but with much lighter resistance than normal. Six weeks out I was pretty much back to normal although I had to be careful with the ab crunches for a couple of months. Sometimes I felt it wasn't good to do as many as usual. You'll know. You will probably need access to a good gym to find machines that totally isolate your upper body. Anyway, that's my story. Your mileage may vary. This isn't medical advice. Blah, blah. Good luck on your surgery, and sorry you have to be here. Dan

Posts.Title: Wishing Everyone a Merry Christmas!

Posts.Content: Well, Scorpio, it's like this. You obviously care enough about your outcomes to have come here looking for advice. My advice is to widen your surgeon pool to more than two. And don't consider any of them who don't have at least 1000 procedures under their belt. Preferably more than that. The "300" number is bandied about quite a bit as the learning curve for the robot, but that doesn't necessarily get the surgeon to the peak of his game. Ask about their outcomes in terms of getting all the cancer out and what percentage of their patients experience ED or incontinence and for how long. ED and incontinence pretty much go hand in hand with a prostatectomy, but the best surgeons have lots better outcomes. They should be able to give you those numbers. If they can't, walk. There aren't any do-overs with a prostatectomy; if the surgeon messes up your surgery, you're screwed. You want the guy who gets all the cancer out, his patients don't need salvage treatment, they can hold their urine after a reasonable amount of time, and don't need dick injections or an implant to have sex when it's all over. That will undoubtably be a guy with thousands of procedures behind him. Not saying that a guy with 600 can't accomplish the same thing, but this game is all about playing the percentages. And the percentages fall heavily in favor of the more experienced surgeons. Let the other guy be the guinea pig.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by SDH Hi all, My Ur does robotic and standard surgeries, and has done hundreds. I was surprised when he told me that he thought I was a better candidate for open surgery since that way, he could easily remove the lymph nodes during surgery. He told me that removing them with robotic was difficult. Find another urologist. Now. Nothing wrong with open surgery, but to say that robotic is more difficult and that he can't get the lymph nodes easily tells me he isn't experienced enough in either procedure. "Hundreds"? What does that mean? One hundred opens and one hundred robotics? You need to be going to a guy who measures his procedures in the thousands, not the hundreds. Sounds to me like he isn't comfortable with the robot, and even "hundreds" of opens woudn't give me warm and fuzzies. I would tend to agree, given the limited information we have, that a prostatectomy is probably your best choice. But if you want to be continent and have any sexual function left afterwards (not to mention negative margins and no cancer left behind), you need to find a surgeon who really knows what the hell he's doing. And that guy hasn't done just "hundreds". Welcome to the board, by the way. Sorry you're here.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Rudyh I really liked my urologist he is on the younger side and have read good things about him. He is in a larger group of urologist that all have some sort of awards. My only concern is that he has close to 300 surgeries with the Da vinchi and he has a senior doctor with him and they both do the surgery. My urologist is on the younger side, also, and seems very knowledgeable. But I wouldn't let him operate on me, and he understood why. The fact that your guy has someone else assisting (training?) him is a big red flag to me. I'd be finding me someone who has over 1,000 robotics under his belt and doesn't need to have a senior doctor in the room with him. Good luck, and sorry to meet you.

Posts.Content: Well, I'm not a doctor but 1/2 a pill per day for a year sounds a little excessive. I took 1/2 (25mg) twice a week and a 50 on whoopee day. I only did the 1/2 pills twice a week for 6 months or so. The objective is to get the blood flowing down there early on to promote healing, etc. Cialis has a 30 day free trial. You could also ask the doc to prescribe 100 mg tablets and quarter them (assuming your husband is taking 25 mg now). Once the healing is well under way, there are other ways to get the blood flowing....

Posts.Title: Dad has PC...

Posts.Content: Welcome and sorry you had to find us. The good news is your relatively low PSA and only two positive cores. At your age and with your numbers, I'd seriously consider surgery. The younger you are the easier it is to recover, and with an experienced surgeon you would have an excellent chance of ridding yourself of the cancer and of regaining potency and continence. There's a lot of questions about the long-term effects of radiation that you would want to educate yourself on if you chose that route. If you do opt for surgery, it is crucial to find a surgeon with boatloads of experience and a history of good outcomes (he should have all those numbers available for you). If he hasn't done at least 500 Da Vinci's, stay away. You're looking for the guy who's done several thousand. As far as being fearful of the possible side effects, remember that job one is to cure the cancer. But if you handle it right and everything goes well, you can hit the trifecta too (no cancer, no incontinence, and regaining sexual function). Good luck to you. Dan

Posts.Title: Diagnosed 5 days ago. Still in the fog stage. Could use some support.

Posts.Content: Welcome and hope you get a good pathology report. I stuck with the nighttime bag all the time, but I didn't go to work or anything before the catheter was removed. I just wore sweats and humped the big bag around. One reason was that I was told that every time you switch bags, you increase the risk of infection. I just set the bag on the floor next to the bed at night. Good luck! Dan

Posts.Title: Sore but relieved

Posts.Content: During a robotic prostatectomy they put the patient in a steep-Trendelenburg position. This not only puts more pressure on the chest cavity but forces the heart to pump harder to move blood to the lower extremities (which during the surgery are the upper extremities). The fact that you knew you had a cardiac problem "EKG showed a little abnormality. In the last 3 weeks I have seen no less than 4 Dr.'s no one said anything about another workup. Had stress test a year ago due to this" leads me to believe that somebody dropped the ball regarding your suitability for a robotic surgery. They shouldn't have waited until two days before your surgery to figure this out. Best of luck! Dan

Posts.Title: Dad has PC...

Posts.Content: Welcome and sorry you had to find us. The good news is your relatively low PSA and only two positive cores. At your age and with your numbers, I'd seriously consider surgery. The younger you are the easier it is to recover, and with an experienced surgeon you would have an excellent chance of ridding yourself of the cancer and of regaining potency and continence. There's a lot of questions about the long-term effects of radiation that you would want to educate yourself on if you chose that route. If you do opt for surgery, it is crucial to find a surgeon with boatloads of experience and a history of good outcomes (he should have all those numbers available for you). If he hasn't done at least 500 Da Vinci's, stay away. You're looking for the guy who's done several thousand. As far as being fearful of the possible side effects, remember that job one is to cure the cancer. But if you handle it right and everything goes well, you can hit the trifecta too (no cancer, no incontinence, and regaining sexual function). Good luck to you. Dan

Posts.Title: Applying For Membership And Seeking Advice

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by hunter548 I currently have another PSA and biopsy scheduled for February to confirm the diagnosis, What's the point? As johnT stated, have your urologist send the slides out for a second opinion. If you have cancer now, you will still have cancer in February. If the February biopsy comes back showing cancer, well, then you still have cancer. If it comes back clear, then the biopsy needles missed the tumor. Biopsy results more often understate the extent of prostate cancer than overstate it. If you do have G8, I wouldn't mess around for three more months waiting to confirm something you already know. Dan

Posts.Title: Ramblings first week post Catheter

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by 2b-lucky I feel okay with the UCLA pathologist. He’s young, but a 3+3 diagnosis is relatively easy to make (per my niece, who is a Johns Hopkins trained pathologist) and the UCLA department head signed off on it. Thank you, guys. Reading the slides isn't the problem. The problem is hitting the worst part of the cancer with the biopsy needles. If the pathologist doesn't get the sample with the G9 in it, then he can't diagnose G9. And even if one of the needles hits the G9 (or whatever), that doesn't necessarily mean that the slice they shave off to send to the pathologist will have the G9 cells in it. Maybe they sliced off the part with the G6 and left the G9 in the petrie dish.

Posts.Title: Applying For Membership And Seeking Advice

Posts.Content: Hi, Imp. There's a separate HIFU thread above but let me say this. I seriously considered HIFU also, and was all but ready to plunk down my money. However, I began to have some serious concerns about medical ethics and conflicts of interest within the HIFU medical community. One of my concerns was discovering instances where doctors performed the procedure despite indications that it wouldn't be appropriate. HIFU isn't for everybody. Also it appeared that most, if not all, of the doctors performing the procedure had a vested interest in the companies producing the machines. The majority of the articles I read that gave HIFU rave reviews were by doctors who had a financial interest in HIFU outside of their normal surgical fees. This is not a judgment about the efficacy of HIFU at all, but do your due diligence before making the leap. Good luck - Dan.

Posts.Title: Low grade tumor abuts capsule. Is Active Surveillance risky?

Posts.Content: Hey Scott, sorry you're here. At your age, I'd be heading for surgery. And with that PSA, I wouldn't be dallying any. I'd want to be rid of that prostate before the G6 becomes a G7 or G8. Did you get a second read on the slides? That would be a good idea. And don't forget that biopsy results don't reveal the true extent of cancer 20-30 percent of the time. That was the clincher for me. I didn't want to mess around and then later find out I had a more aggressive cancer than the biopsy revealed.

Posts.Content: Yes, that's the prostatecomy trifecta. Cancer gone, no incontinence to speak of, and the ability to achieve erections. I was probably 95% continent or better right after the catheter came out. After a couple of months I pretty much considered myself fully continent. I only have an occasional drip with a full bladder if I'm not paying attention. But those are very infrequent. I was able to have sex about three weeks after surgery, but good erections took a few months to return. I take Viagra, but could probably do without. But Viagra rocks.

Posts.Content: Well if you're doing them right your abdominal muscles shouldn't even come into play, so my suspicion is that you're doing them wrong. Should feel like you're sucking your testicles up into your anus. Takes a little practice. If you do a Google search you can find some hints. Two sets of 10 every day was enough for me; after 6-8 months I just quit doing them altogether. Your mileage may vary. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Getting Biopsy in Two Weeks

Posts.Content: Well, let me just say this. After interviewing three surgeons and researching many more, I flew 7,000 miles to have Dr. Wilson do my prostatectomy. And the results couldn't have been better. Hit the trifecta. Dr. Kawachi at City of Hope has a reputation equally as impressive as Dr. Wilson's. City of Hope was great. They have some cottages you can rent for something like $60 a night. I stayed there for a week doing my initial recuperation. Just a walk across the street to the hospital for follow-ups, etc. Made life pretty easy for the wife, also. They have free buses so I made sure she got out to take a break from being around me too much. Get the hair done, etc. Things just couldn't have gone better for me there. The grounds are also fantastic and they have a meditation garden, etc. Plenty of space to go for the frequent post-surgery walks and have some solitude. Well needed after the surgery, I'll tell you. Good luck. Dan

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by wishbone but you can live forever with a 3+3. Problem is, you don't really KNOW it's a 3+3 until it's out. Maybe the biopsy missed some of the tumor. And it may become a 4+3 or something more aggressive and gets missed on a couple of biopsies while you're doing your "waiting". Read the signature lines on this board, they're rife with pathology reports that are much worse than the biopsy reports.

Posts.Title: Does that Cancer really need to be removed ?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Tazz Which one will do the best job to #1, get rid of all the cancer, #2, prohibit me from becoming incontinent, #3, prohibit me from having ED? I am so stressed over all of this that I just want someone to tell me who the best surgeon is that will give me the best outcome at the best hospital w/out having my wife and family travel far nor myself. Hi, Tazz. Sorry you're here. You're saying you want the best possible care and outcomes, but then you say you don't want to travel to get them. That's not the right perspective to come at this problem with, especially at your age. Finding the right surgeon is not all that difficult, you have made a good start by coming here. If you're like me and several others here, you will decide that the inconvenience and expense associated with obtaining top-notch care, no matter where you have to go to get it, is well worth it. Or you can stay local, let whoever hack you up, and hope for the best. I would say that I narrowed my list of prospective surgeons down to not more than a half-dozen in the entire country. Guys with thousands of procedures under their belts and the outcomes that come with that experience level. Besides what you learn here, US News has lists of the best doctors and hospitals, you can Google it. Often you will find the surgeon's or hospital's web sites will list outcomes in detail. If they don't, you can ask. If they won't or can't tell you, walk away. The top-notch guys are rightfully proud of their outcomes and won't hesitate to tell you. Good Luck Dan

Posts.Title: diagnosed with prostate cancer at age 41

Posts.Content: I'd go for the biopsy. Your PSA numbers and and DRE results are very similar to mine. It's real easy to miss cancer with a biopsy, if you don't believe it check out some of the signatures of the guys here. Years of negative biopsy results and then, boom. As an example, I had a 12 core done last year. I had the results interpreted by three hospitals. One of the hospitals reported exactly what you have, 11 cores negative and 1 core 1% or less. Yet I had cancer occupying 20% of my prostate. Sometimes a needle misses the tumor altogether, sometimes it just nicks it. Or it depends on how they slice the core samples. The two other reads of my biopsy showed 40% in one core. Yet still, with a tumor occupying 20% of the prostate you would think at least two needles would have shown positive. So you can see that biopsy results can be hit or miss. Your "suspicious cells" could very well have been the outer edge of a real tumor. With a family history of prostate cancer, I wouldn't screw around. I would recommend having your guy send samples of your last biopsy out to another pathologist for interpretation. Oh, yeah. Welcome to the board. Our hope is that you don't become a "real" member. Dan

Posts.Title: Finally some good news!

Posts.Content: I'd go for the biopsy. Your PSA numbers and and DRE results are very similar to mine. It's real easy to miss cancer with a biopsy, if you don't believe it check out some of the signatures of the guys here. Years of negative biopsy results and then, boom. As an example, I had a 12 core done last year. I had the results interpreted by three hospitals. One of the hospitals reported exactly what you have, 11 cores negative and 1 core 1% or less. Yet I had cancer occupying 20% of my prostate. Sometimes a needle misses the tumor altogether, sometimes it just nicks it. Or it depends on how they slice the core samples. The two other reads of my biopsy showed 40% in one core. Yet still, with a tumor occupying 20% of the prostate you would think at least two needles would have shown positive. So you can see that biopsy results can be hit or miss. Your "suspicious cells" could very well have been the outer edge of a real tumor. With a family history of prostate cancer, I wouldn't screw around. I would recommend having your guy send samples of your last biopsy out to another pathologist for interpretation. Oh, yeah. Welcome to the board. Our hope is that you don't become a "real" member. Dan

Posts.Title: advice please??

Posts.Content: I explored SBRT as a salvage treatment quite recently as I had a blood test that indicated recurrence after a prostatectomy (turns out they had done a "regular" PSA test; it was redone with an ultrasensitive test and came back fine). SBRT has gained acceptance as a primary treatment, but not for salvage treatment. There are a couple of clinical trials going on right now at City of Hope and the University of Virginia using SBRT for salvage treatment. However, I wasn't getting warm fuzzies about them and after consulting a radiation oncologist at a well-known teaching hospital I had pretty much written off SBRT as a salvage treatment. Fortunately, I didn't have to make that decision.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by drakebullet What therapies/practices have been helpful for you? Put it to work. You don't need an erection to have sex or achieve orgasm, and it will benefit you psychologically and physically. I was back at it 17 days post-surgery. Don't expect great results for a while and both of you need to be mentally prepared for occasional (or even frequent) failures. No big deal. Keep trying. You will probably find that the directions tell you to wait about an hour after eating, I have found that an empty stomach is best. Way, way better than any attempts within a few hours after a meal. Have fun.

Posts.Content: The saturation biopsy has a better chance of hitting any cancer that might be present, and possibly hitting some higher grade stuff that might be missed on a regular biopsy. There are several surgeons with 6000 or more procedures, they get mixed reviews as some of them cherry pick their patients to keep their outcomes looking good. Which is not necessarily a bad thing if they're willing to take you as a patient. I wasn't quite comfortable going the assembly line route so I found a guy with several thousand procedures but didn't make it his life's work to crank out as many prostatectomies as he could. Glad to hear you're willing to travel to find the right surgeon, it can make all the difference in the world. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Dealing with prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Tom - It only took me a couple of weeks to reach my decision and act, and I was only a G6. Based on your numbers, you do not have the luxury of time on your side. If I had your numbers, I'd already be planning a treatment strategy or two and be ready to execute one of them ASAP. Don't be surprised on the final pathology report (should you choose surgery) to find you have some G8 or G9 hiding in there that the needles missed. Bottom line is you need to choose the treatment that has the best chance of curing the cancer, otherwise you won't be around to take care of your wife. Not to mention the expenses involved with extensive treatment, hospitalization, drugs, hospice, etc. etc. if you DON'T get cured.

Posts.Title: Questions about Viagra/Generic Viagra

Posts.Content: Sorry you're here. The 9's mean you've got some real cancer and don't have a whole lot of time to waste. Get Walsh's book for starters and hit the American Cancer Society's web site. Learn everything you can. A lot will depend on the results of the bone/cat scan. But ultimately you are the guy who will be responsible for your treatment plan, so you need to bone up and become a PCa expert. I was a Gleason 6, so my decisions were fairly easy. Your's will be a little more complicated, but there's guys here who were in the same boat and will be able to offer you some excellent advice. Best of luck to you.

Posts.Title: mixed gleason , psa31

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by mariod PSA 11 , Gleason 6, small tumor, 16 samples taken 5% positive in one sample only. I'll be the contrarian. Given your age and those numbers, my gut reaction is that they either missed a large chunk of the tumor, misread the slides, or your PSA test was wrong. Or perhaps you also have an enlarged prostate that is contributing to the high PSA readings. I wouldn't even consider "alternative therapies" until I got another read of the biopsy results (which will be a different slice than the original) and had a second biopsy. When they do a pathology report, they don't look at the whole sample, just a slice of it. Sorry that this won't serve to calm you down, but on the surface those numbers just don't jive in my opinion. Something's going on that you need to know about before making a treatment decision, and it may very well not be a G6 tumor in 5% of your prostate. Good Luck - Dan

Posts.Title: Da Vinci robotic prostatectomy recovery-

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by mariod PSA 11 , Gleason 6, small tumor, 16 samples taken 5% positive in one sample only. I'll be the contrarian. Given your age and those numbers, my gut reaction is that they either missed a large chunk of the tumor, misread the slides, or your PSA test was wrong. Or perhaps you also have an enlarged prostate that is contributing to the high PSA readings. I wouldn't even consider "alternative therapies" until I got another read of the biopsy results (which will be a different slice than the original) and had a second biopsy. When they do a pathology report, they don't look at the whole sample, just a slice of it. Sorry that this won't serve to calm you down, but on the surface those numbers just don't jive in my opinion. Something's going on that you need to know about before making a treatment decision, and it may very well not be a G6 tumor in 5% of your prostate. Good Luck - Dan

Posts.Content: Just let me say a couple of things: I briefly considered HIFU and was almost ready to put my money down. But the more I read the more red flags kept popping up, like doctors performing HIFU on patients they really shouldn't have, etc. Second, virtually every "study" you will come across was published by somebody with close ties (financial interest) to the manufacturer of the machines, as does almost every doctor who performs it.

Posts.Title: QUESTION ABOUT BIOPSY _Got 0 OF !2 NEG

Posts.Content: I considered myself to be 90-95% continent right after the catheter came out (one week). I now consider myself to be 100% continent for all intents and purposes, and have been since roughly three months or so after surgery. I still get an occasional squirt, but it's typically when I have a full bladder, stretch or move suddenly, and I'm not paying attention. All bets are off after 8 beers, though. As far as the rest of the plumbing, I was ops-checking it 17 days after surgery. Nothing to write home about, but better than nothing. Within a few months, with a little Viagra, it was real good. Now, with a Viagra, I feel like a hormone-charged teenager in the back seat of the old man's car at the drive-in theater. I think I could probably wean myself off the Viagra, but what the heck for? BTW, I quit doing kegels altogether several months ago just because I didn't feel like doing them any longer. All is well.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by mariod PSA 11 , Gleason 6, small tumor, 16 samples taken 5% positive in one sample only. I'll be the contrarian. Given your age and those numbers, my gut reaction is that they either missed a large chunk of the tumor, misread the slides, or your PSA test was wrong. Or perhaps you also have an enlarged prostate that is contributing to the high PSA readings. I wouldn't even consider "alternative therapies" until I got another read of the biopsy results (which will be a different slice than the original) and had a second biopsy. When they do a pathology report, they don't look at the whole sample, just a slice of it. Sorry that this won't serve to calm you down, but on the surface those numbers just don't jive in my opinion. Something's going on that you need to know about before making a treatment decision, and it may very well not be a G6 tumor in 5% of your prostate. Good Luck - Dan

Posts.Content: Yeah, I don't want to rain on your parade either, but as stated above a negative biopsy could mean they just missed the tumor. Or when they sliced off a piece for the pathology report they missed it. I only had one positive core but the tumor occupied 20% of the prostate, and they did a 12 core biopsy. Plus, I had two different pathology reports, one reported 40% of one core and the other only 1% because of how they sliced it. Something's causing your numbers, you need to be aggressive until you find out for sure what. Best of luck to you.

Posts.Title: Just Diagnosed

Posts.Content: I considered myself to be 90-95% continent right after the catheter came out (one week). I now consider myself to be 100% continent for all intents and purposes, and have been since roughly three months or so after surgery. I still get an occasional squirt, but it's typically when I have a full bladder, stretch or move suddenly, and I'm not paying attention. All bets are off after 8 beers, though. As far as the rest of the plumbing, I was ops-checking it 17 days after surgery. Nothing to write home about, but better than nothing. Within a few months, with a little Viagra, it was real good. Now, with a Viagra, I feel like a hormone-charged teenager in the back seat of the old man's car at the drive-in theater. I think I could probably wean myself off the Viagra, but what the heck for? BTW, I quit doing kegels altogether several months ago just because I didn't feel like doing them any longer. All is well.

Posts.Title: Excruciating pain where urine leaves body 4 weeks after foley cath removal. Why???

Posts.Content: I was 55 at diagnosis, one positive core, Gleason 6. I briefly considered AS. Decided I didn't want to risk my life on variables and unknowns. Way too many guys here whose pathology reports after surgery were much worse than their biopsies indicated. So I just wanted it gone and to know with (reasonable) certainty what I was dealing with. Plus I considered that at my age I would probably have to get it treated eventually anyway, and didn't want to wait around until I got older and make recovery more difficult. Not to mention regaining continence and potency, which seems to be easier the younger you are. Just my opinion.

Posts.Title: Young man with confusing options

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Mikla • Will you do the entire surgery? Now there's a REAL important question, and one that a lot of guys may overlook. It doesn't matter how many procedures your guy has done if he is going to turn the controls over to his trainee halfway through. This is particularly important if you are having your procedure at a teaching hospital. I made it real clear that I didn't fly 7,000 miles to be operated on by the new guy, and my surgeon assured me that he would personally perform the entire procedure.

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear you've joined us, Dunbar. Walsh's book is a good read, another I'd recommend is Winning the Battle Against Prostate Cancer by Gerald Chodak, MD. A little more up to date and covers some different territory than Walsh's. I bought them both, they complement each other. As Replicant stated, your age is a factor and you'll probably find surgery is the recommendation you'll hear most often. But you have to select the treatment that's right for YOU. You would have a better chance of regaining continency and potency after surgery at your younger age, also. If you do choose surgery, find a guy that's done at least 300 procedures. Preferably way more. Prostatectomies are definitely a practice makes perfect operation. If you're going to go robotic, the guy needs to have at least 300 of those under his belt, also. You don't get a do-over, so do it right the first time. I flew 7,000 miles to get a surgeon and hospital I was comfortable with, but understandably not everyone has the resources to do that. Point is, don't limit yourself to the guy close by if you don't feel he can give you the outcomes you desire and you have the ability to travel. Best of luck to you. You're going to find the next month or so to be the most difficult time as you digest all you're about to learn, which makes you realize how much you still have to learn. Then you have to translate all of that into your own treatment plan. Fortunately there's a wealth of experienced guys here to help you along.

Posts.Title: Question about follow-up appt after Davinci

Posts.Content: As johnT said, a second biopsy is imperative. Biopsies frequently understate the extent/aggressiveness of the cancer. I considered AS when I was diagnosed too, but two things kept me from it. One was that I just didn't want to risk the biopsy being wrong about the extent (it was wrong) or the aggressiveness (it was right) of the cancer. Yeah, I could have had another biopsy, but I just wanted the cancer gone. The second reason was that assuming I would eventually have to deal with it because of my relatively young age (55), I'd rather do it sooner than later as sooner would give me a much better chance of recovering potency and continence, which I have for the most part. At any rate, everybody has to be comfortable with their decision and treatment plan. Good luck.

Posts.Title: The Rocco stitch

Posts.Content: Let me join the "don't do it" chorus. First of all, you're going to be bloated as hell from the gas they inject into your abdomen. You need to spend several days, at a minimum, walking as often as you can stand it to get the gas out. It can be fairly uncomfortable if not painful at times. Not to mention the issues with bowel movements (or lack of), bleeding from the incisions, etc etc. Do yourself a favor and spend a few days in a hotel before you travel.

Posts.Title: Home from surgery

Posts.Content: Let me join the "don't do it" chorus. First of all, you're going to be bloated as hell from the gas they inject into your abdomen. You need to spend several days, at a minimum, walking as often as you can stand it to get the gas out. It can be fairly uncomfortable if not painful at times. Not to mention the issues with bowel movements (or lack of), bleeding from the incisions, etc etc. Do yourself a favor and spend a few days in a hotel before you travel.

Posts.Title: Travel

Posts.Content: No real surprises there, we all know that many men have diagnosed/undiagnosed nonaggressive prostate cancer and live long lives without treatment and die of other causes. The problem is that you can't really be certain what kind of cancer you have; a biopsy is only a best guess and wrong around 30 percent of the time.
